items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p><jats:italic>Clostridium perfringens </jats:italic>isolates were obtained from pigs of five porcine farms in Poland. The presence of <jats:italic>C. perfringens</jats:italic> was detected in 92% of faeces samples and its number ranged from 1.0 x 101 cfu/g to 1.2 x 107 cfu/g. All the isolates belonged to type A and 48.7% of them contained <jats:italic>cpb2 </jats:italic>gene. The qualitative assessment of toxin genes expression by type A subtype β2 isolates showed expression of <jats:italic>cpa </jats:italic>gene in 100% of strains and <jats:italic>cpb2 </jats:italic>gene in 71% of the analysed strains. The isolate from one-day-old piglets demonstrated also the expression of <jats:italic>cpa </jats:italic>and <jats:italic>cpb2 </jats:italic>genes.</jats:p>
title: Occurrence and Expression of Toxin Genes in Clostridium Perfringens Isolates from Pigs
container-title: Bulletin of the Veterinary Institute in Pulawy

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> The study was conducted at all regional veterinary diagnostic laboratories. Feed materials were examined for Salmonella prevalence and contamination by Enterobacteriaceae, aerobic mesophilic bacteria, total plate count, fungi, Clostridium sp., and Bacillus cereus. Assays were done following international and Polish standards used in food and feed microbiology. Salmonella sp. were most often detected in oil seeds. In most of the examined feed ingredients, the number of Enterobacteriaceae did not exceed 10 cfu/g. The contamination by aerobic bacteria ranged most often from 101to 107 cfu/g, and the highest mycological contamination was noted in cereal grains (10<jats:sup>8</jats:sup> cfu/g). The results showed that microbial contamination of feed materials in regard to Enterobacteriaceae, fungi, and total plate counts declined over the past years.</jats:p>
title: Microbiological quality of feed materials used between 2009 and 2012 in Poland
container-title: Bulletin of the Veterinary Institute in Pulawy

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>As the test material mink feed with natural microflora was used. The analyses were conducted using Wrzosek and TPGY broth media, and Willis–Hobbs and Zeissler differential agar media. Wrzosek, Willis–Hobbs, and Zeissler media are described in Polish Standards approved by the National Standards Body in Poland and routinely used in detection of anaerobic bacteria in Poland. Detection and identification of <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> was performed with a previously validated real-time PCR method based on <jats:italic>ntnh</jats:italic> gene detection, which is common in all <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> toxotypes. The use of Wrzosek broth and Zeissler agar in routine analyses for detection and identification of <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> was ineffective and limited. The obtained results showed the highest culturing process effectiveness in TPGY broth with 72 h incubation at 30°C and isolation on Willis–Hobbs agar. The real-time PCR method based on <jats:italic>ntnh</jats:italic> gene detection used in this study could be utilised as a supplementary tool to the mouse lethality assay.</jats:p>
title: Optimisation of protocol for Clostridium botulinum detection in mink feed

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> The aim of this study was to perform an in-house validation of multiplex PCR method for <jats:italic>C. botulinum </jats:italic>detection in food and feed samples. The study was carried out on food and feed matrixes artificially contaminated by spores of <jats:italic>C. botulinum </jats:italic>reference strains. The following characteristic parameters for qualitative detection were estimated: limit of detection expressed as LOD50 according to the Spearman-Kärber formula, specificity, sensitivity, and accuracy according to the PN-EN ISO 16140:2004. The validated method showed high specificity. Specific PCR products were revealed only for DNA obtained from samples contaminated with <jats:italic>C. botulinum </jats:italic>spores. PCR inhibition was observed, especially during examination of contaminated feed. The calculated LOD50 for feed was nearly 10 times higher than for food. The implemented method enables to obtain test results during 3 d without time- consuming process of isolation and proving the ability of strains to produce botulinum toxins.</jats:p>
title: In-House Validation of Multiplex PCR Method for Detection of Clostridium Botulinum in Food and Feed
container-title: Bulletin of the Veterinary Institute in Pulawy

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>A PCR-based procedure for detection of <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> C and D in corn silage samples was validated. During the validation, method specificity, sensitivity, and accuracy were determined according to PN - EN ISO 16140:2004. Additionally, the specificity of the validated methods was proved by sequence analysis of PCR products obtained from examination of samples connected with botulism cases in cattle and mallard ducks. Limit of detection was estimated according to the Spearman - Kärber formula and expressed as LOD<jats:sc>50.</jats:sc> The obtained results showed that a 100% specificity was achieved. The sequencing of PCR products revealed 99% identity with sequences of <jats:italic>bont/C</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>bont/D</jats:italic> genes deposited in the GenBank. The sensitivity value ranged from 63.3% for <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> type C to 75% for type D. The accuracy value varied from 72% for type C to 81.3% for type D. LOD<jats:sc>50</jats:sc> was estimated at the levels of 0.272 (0. D 188-0395) spore/g for type C and 0.17 (0.1-0.289) spore/g for type D. The described PCR-based procedure enabled detection of <jats:italic>C. botulinum</jats:italic> C and D at the stage of liquid culture. This makes examination of feed samples possible without isolation process. The presented procedure could support the diagnosis of botulism by faster and specific laboratory examination process.</jats:p>
title: In-house Validation of PCR Based Procedure for Specific Detection of Clostridium Botulinum Types C and D
container-title: Bulletin of the Veterinary Institute in Pulawy

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> Introduction: The aim of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of Clostridium botulinum and Clostridium perfringens in food samples purchased from Polish producers. Material and Methods: The analyses were performed on 260 food samples collected in Lublin and Subcarpathian regions: 56 of smoked meat, 21 of pork meat, 20 of dairy products, 26 of vegetable and fruit preserves, 40 of ready-to-eat meals, 27 of fish preserves, and 70 of honey collected directly from apiaries. Results: C. botulinum strains were isolated from 2.3% (6/260) of samples and the isolates were classified as toxin types A (4/260) and B (2/260). C. perfringens strains were isolated from 14% (37/260) of samples. All the isolates were classified as toxin type A, 28 of them were able also to produce α toxin and 9 - β2 toxin. Conclusion: On the basis of the obtained results it could be suggested that risk assessment, especially regarding the entire honey harvesting process, should be provided in order to ensure the microbiological safety of the products to be consumed by infants and people with a weakened immune system.</jats:p>
title: Prevalence of C. botulinum and C. perfringens spores in food products available on Polish market

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p><jats:bold>Introduction:</jats:bold> The aim of this study was examination of honey samples collected from apiaries situated in all Polish provinces for occurrence of <jats:italic>Clostridium</jats:italic> spp., especially <jats:italic>C. perfringens</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
<jats:p><jats:bold>Material and Methods:</jats:bold> The study was carried out on 240 honey samples (15 samples/province). Estimation of <jats:italic>Clostridium</jats:italic> titre, its cultures and <jats:italic>C. perfringens</jats:italic> isolate characterisation were performed according to the standard PN-R-64791:1994. A multiplex PCR method for detection of genes coding <jats:italic>cpa</jats:italic> (α toxin), <jats:italic>cpb</jats:italic> (β), <jats:italic>cpb2</jats:italic> (β2), <jats:italic>etx</jats:italic> (ε), <jats:italic>iap</jats:italic> (ι), and <jats:italic>cpe</jats:italic> (enterotoxin) toxins was used.</jats:p>
<jats:p><jats:bold>Results:</jats:bold> <jats:italic>Clostridium</jats:italic> spp. was noticed in 56% (136/240) of samples, and its titres ranged between 0.1 g and 0.001 g. <jats:italic>Clostridium perfringens</jats:italic> occurrence was evidenced in 27.5% (66/240) of samples. All isolates were classified to toxinotype A.</jats:p>
<jats:p><jats:bold>Conclusions:</jats:bold> Evidence of a high number of positive samples with occurrence of <jats:italic>Clostridium</jats:italic> spp. indicates a potential risk to consumers’ health. The infective number of <jats:italic>Clostridium</jats:italic> spp. is unknown; however, the obtained results have shown that a risk assessment on the entire honey harvesting process should be made in order to ensure microbiological safety. Moreover, a detailed study should be undertaken on the antibiotic resistance of <jats:italic>C. perfringens</jats:italic> isolates from honey samples.</jats:p>
title: Clostridium perfringens spores in Polish honey samples
subject: General Veterinary
